September is Suicide Prevention Awareness Month, and this week is awareness week. This is a time to bring more awareness, start conversations, and reduce stigma regarding mental health and talking about suicide prevention.

Olentangy Schools prioritizes the health and well-being of our students and staff, and want to ensure we all know how to help others in need. Olentangy students receive Signs of Suicide curriculum in 7th grade and high school health classes, while our staff receive Kognito prevention training. Kognito is a role-play simulation for educators that builds awareness, knowledge, and skills about mental health and suicide prevention, and prepares our staff to lead real-life conversations with students that build resilience, strengthen relationships, and connect them with support.

If you or someone you know needs help, contact Olentangy‚Äôs anonymous Stay Safe, Speak Up tip line.
https://staysafespeakup.app/Welcome/district/OLSD

The Teacher of the Year we‚Äôre recognizing today is Danielle Gillespie from Olentangy Liberty Middle School. Ms. Gillespie is an 8th grade teacher who meets her students where they are at, and even built standing desks for students in her classroom that had difficulty sitting still. This is what one of her colleagues had to say:

‚ÄúDanielle has an innate ability to create opportunities for students to be themselves in her classroom environment. During her lunch period, she opened up her classroom for students to come in during their lunch, eat, chat, and color with Mrs. Gillespie a few times a week. She understands the stress of being an 8th grader and the feeling of calm that can come from coloring with friends. If you popped in her room, you would see giant coloring pages on the floor, lunch being eaten and many students comfortably sprawled on the floor, de-stressing from the day and building relationships with all who came. And many did, including fellow colleagues and our principal.

Congratulations Ms. Gillespie!

Olentangy Orange Middle School started a Living History Speaker Series this year to give students a chance to learn about history in an engaging way. Once per quarter, the school invites in a speaker who is an expert about a time in history or who has experienced an event in history and has a story to tell.

Last year, OOMS had a 9/11 survivor come in during lunch. Students could sign up to attend and eat lunch while learning from the speaker. It was a huge success, and that's how the Living History Speaker Series was born.

The school's first speaker this year was a collector and expert on WWI and WWII. He taught students about WWII through his amazing artifacts in his collection and the students loved it.

The next speaker is scheduled for December 13.
